author: TomboyPlayer1993

text: Yes, the rest of the game was(for the most part) light and cheerful. But I just said that the ENDING was dark. And the rest of the game wasn't entirely happy-go-lucky either. The ending was built up throughout a large portion of the game, as each boss you killed (starting with Slime Eel) warned against waking the Wind Fish. That, along with the ominous message at the southern Face Shrine and what some owl statues said, created a sense of dread that contrasted with the game's lighter tones.
author: Great Eyewarp

text: Not dark? Link's actions end up destroying the entire world you've been exploring throughout the entire game. You watch as everything and everyone you've grown to know and love over the course of your journey is annihilated and Koholint Island is wiped from existence. Link brings Koholint to an end so that he may return to Hyrule. The whole ending has a sort of "lesser evil for the greater good" theme to it, sacrificing Koholint for Hyrule. Is that not a dark ending?
author: Great Eyewarp

text: ehh, it was kinda disappoining, i wouldnt say dark though.

Man.... This theme.... I need to push on. I am lost as can be sometimes. But isn't the whole magic of the Zelda series to enjoy the world within as well as places and secrets you'll find? That is the whole charm, and well worth of the name "Adventure games". Even the old NES ones. 
One does not simply hate a Zelda game. I liked all of them, and I played every one of them.

author: Tela Huele

text:
When I was a kid, I always swore to never be a 'nostalgic old fogey', who longs for the "good old days" about anything, and embrace everything right about the new. But... the old days of gaming... they really did seem so much better. I miss them.

When I was a kid, I didn't think gaming would change like it has. There are still plenty of good new games, true. But things just aren't the same. They aren't quite as good. It's just.... it's just not the same. It's not the 16-Bit era.

author: BalmungMP5

text:
@superearthbender Well, that is true, I don't see the point in forcing your childs to play it either. What I'm referring to is that you said he enjoys Zelda because of nostalgia and not because of its greatness. That means to me: It's not good, you like it because you didn't now anything better and due to nostalgia you think it's great.
If you didn't mean it like this then I misinterpreted it. My point is just, that one might still enjoy it today even though he never played it.
author: Marcel

text:
@superearthbender Pong is video game-history. Not respecting Pong is like spitting on videogames. As i said, gameplay developed. Still old games are fun to play. Lots of them got art, soundtracks, stories or ideas that make it worth to play although it might be a bit "basic" in their gameplay. I played an old NES game 1-2 years ago that i never played before and it was fun, even if you feel that its old when you play it(It was released before my birth btw)
Keep you opinion idc.
